intro: Bupleurum gilesii, commonly known as the mountain angelica, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the carrot family. Bupleurum gilesii thrives in well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade, often growing in rocky or alpine environments. Its botanical features make it an important species for ecological studies and traditional medicine.
